fields.description:
When Bamboo is integrated with Stash and is correctly configured to send notification for "All Builds Completed", the option that is selected for branches is "Notify committers and people who have favourited the created branch" by default. If there are any feature/* branches, Bamboo does not report builds to Stash until the "Use the plan's notification settings" is selected from either under the main plan's branches tab or for each branch separately. 

Please make this more clear since it's causing confusion. 
In the attached screenshots only commit "6e4f614" had the "Use the plan's notification settings" selected.
fields.summary: Builds notifications is not working for branches if use the plan's notification settings is not selected

fields.description: When configuring a branch's Source Repository (SVN), I uncheck the "Enable commit isolation" checkbox and press Save, however that change is not persisted.
fields.summary: Enable Commit Isolation Won't Uncheck And Save In Branch Configuration

fields.description:
It seems that the ability to view Bamboo's available build plans from JIRA's releases is tied to the Bamboo Admin permission (not the Restricted Admin permission). Within the OnDemand platform this permission is restricted to System Administrator level users only, so essentially no JIRA OnDemand users will be able to view the build plans when releasing.

Steps to reproduce:
# login to a JIRA + Bamboo OnDemand instance as a non sysadmin user
# go to the version page and attempt to release the version
# you'll see this: 'Bamboo server has not returned any Plans.'
# log in to the instance as a sysadmin user
# from the Bamboo permissions page add the previous non sysadmin user to the bamboo admin permission
# repeat steps 1 & 2 and see that build plans are now available

Please separate these permissions such that OnDemand non sysadmin users can be granted this permission separate from other restricted operations.
fields.summary: Bamboo permissions block JIRA OnDemand users from seeing build plans in JIRA releases

fields.description:
I've created a video as it's a bit difficult to explain in details.

*Steps*
# Create new version
Note that the latest version off {{develop}} is _1.3.0-SNAPSHOT-53_.
# Switch plan branch to {{hotfix-1.2.1}}
Note that no version was ever created from this branch but it shows: _Last version 1.2.0-RC1_.
# Try to create new version _1.2.1_
Note that when clicking on the _Create release_ button, it reloads but the release is not created and now it shows different version information than before
# Switch back to {{develop}} plan branch
Note that version information is incorrect. It should show version *1.3.0-SNAPSHOT-53*

*Additional notes*
* Release version _1.2.0-RC1_ was created manually off a plan branch which doesn't exist anymore ({{release-1.2.0}})
* Release version _1.3.0-SNAPSHOT-53_ was created automatically when a deployment is triggered through the _After successful build plan_ trigger on the main plan branch ({{develop}}). It uses the following release versioning:
{noformat}
${bamboo.maven.version}-${bamboo.buildNumber}
{noformat}
fields.summary: Unable to create new release off deployment plan branch

Best Regards,

fields.description:
If a build needs to be rerun, and the VCS tagging task already executed on the previous incomplete run, it will fail the build as the tag already exists.

It would be nice to add a checkbox in the task to not fail the build if the tag already exists, and simply write out an info in the log.

This would also be helpful should the VCS tagging task be included in deployment projects (BAM-13942), as I could run a deployment on an environment multiple times.
fields.summary: Add option in VCS Tagging task to not fail build if tag already exists

fields.description:
*Steps to replicate*
# Create a plan In Bamboo and a related deployment project that has 3 environments
# Create an application link between JIRA and Bamboo as required in this guide: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Viewing+deployments+in+JIRA
# Usually if an issue key is referenced in a build that has been deployed, it should be shown on the  view issue panel
# Now if one of on the environments "view" permission has been removed, the number of environments count is still counted as 3 instead of 2. In the screenshot below, it still shows 2 pf 3 environments while it is expected to show 1 of 2 environments
!screenshot.jpg!

If this is not a bug, then its a good candidate for improvement for us to count the environments  taking in to consideration the permissions.

This tested with the latest JIRA bamboo plugin version 7.0.10

fields.description:
While investigating the outage of one of our Bamboo servers, I've seen a lot of the following exceptions like this:
{code}
2014-01-05 19:40:27,390 INFO [elastic-pool-3-thread-7] [InstanceCache] query for a non-existing resource [i-<some-id>]
2014-01-05 19:40:27,390 WARN [elastic-pool-3-thread-7] [RemoteEC2InstanceImpl] The request for the current status of EC2 instance/spot request i-<some-id> failed, try 1.  Will retry later.
Ec2CacheMissException: Status Code: 400, AWS Service: AmazonEC2, AWS Request ID: none, AWS Error Code: InvalidInstanceID.NotFound, AWS Error Message: The resource with ID 'i-<some-id>' does not exist
        at com.atlassian.aws.ec2.caches.InstanceCache.onResourceLookupFailure(InstanceCache.java:56)
        at com.atlassian.aws.AwsOmeCache.filterResources(AwsOmeCache.java:86)

        at com.atlassian.aws.AwsOmeCache.describe(AwsOmeCache.java:107)

        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.runAndReset(FutureTask.java:304)

fields.description:
When performing a deployment linked from a build plan that is configured to use a custom branch, the "Select a release to deploy" option lists build results from the main branch instead of the custom branch:

!http://i.imgur.com/a5mS63s.png!

The workaround is simply to unselect then reselect the plan branch, as shown in this video: http://screencast.com/t/7DMUuXsJB

If you don't know about this, it's pretty easy to accidentally deploy the wrong artifacts.

Encountered on ebiac running 5.3-rc1 build 4101 on [this plan|https://extranet-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/deploy/viewDeploymentProjectEnvironments.action?id=540016642].
fields.summary: Deployment: "Select a release to deploy" view can pick up build results from wrong branch
stopping builds from the plan page shows json content

fields.description:
When an old branch of a project is deleted, it's releases are retained.

What's weird, is that sometimes new branches are connected to these releases, which makes it so you can't make new releases of that branch.

# Make a branch of a project
# Using that branch, create a build with artifacts and a release
# Delete the branch (but not the release)
# Create a new branch
# Using the new branch, create a build with artifacts

Notice that you cannot create a release, and the old release is shown.

Note that this issue only appears on applications with high numbers of branches and releases.

*Work-around* manually delete the old releases until it stops linking.
fields.summary: When old branches are deleted, new branches get connected to their releases

fields.description:
According to this documentation on the REST API: https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bamboo/3.3-SNAPSHOT.html#idp28800 , queuing a build should accept the following content types:
# application/xml 
# application/x-www-form-urlencoded
# application/json

The above two works but fails on the json content type. This causes hooks like the JIRA webhook to fail to trigger a build in Bamboo as by default, it sens outs events in json

I have tried to test this using the URL below:
{code}
curl -u admin:admin -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://10.60.2.181:10520/bamboo52/rest/api/latest/queue/TESTA-TSTA

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If locale setting in the Bamboo Server computer makes the date use a special character, Bamboo will fail to parse the date, returning null.

h3. Environment
Linux with locale settings that use special characters for either days or months.

h3. Steps to reproduce
# In catalina.sh (for Linux), add "user.language=XX" for JAVA_OPTS. For example:
{noformat}
JAVA_OPTS="$JAVA_OPTS $JSSE_OPTS -Duser.language=de -Duser.region=DE"
{noformat}
We are now in March. In german, March is März. The "umlaut" cannot be parsed.
# Run a build. 

h3. Expected results
{noformat}
03-Mar-2017 16:33:55 	JOB1
03-Mar-2017 16:33:55 	going to sleep.
03-Mar-2017 16:33:58 	sleeping done
{noformat}

h3. Actual results
{noformat}
01-Jan-1970 01:00:00 	JOB1
01-Jan-1970 01:00:00 	going to sleep.
01-Jan-1970 01:00:00 	sleeping done
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
# Force tomcat to use english locale:
{noformat}
JAVA_OPTS="$JAVA_OPTS $JSSE_OPTS -Duser.language=en -Duser.region=DE"
{noformat}

-------
Old description

*Steps to replicate*
# Set your system locale to US or UK locale
# Set the region format to German de-CH. See the screenshot
!format.jpg!
# This will cause Bamboo build logs to display the logs all to default date 01-Jan-1970 01:00:00.  If the build logs is hwoever opened or downloaded, the correct timing is shown. See below
!time.jpg!
# This mostly happens in months when the abbreviations are different. In the example above, December is abbreviated as dec in UK/US whereas in German, it dez. For more on the list of month abbreviations see http://library.princeton.edu/departments/tsd/katmandu/reference/months.html  

*workaround*
Please see this [knowledge base article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Wrong+settings+of+the+user+language+and+locale+causes+build+logs+to+be+shown+with+a+default+time+01-Jan-1970+01%3A00%3A00]
fields.summary: The build logs dates default to 01-Jan-1970 01:00:00 if the windows display format is different from the system locale

fields.description:
Having "View" or "Access" selected for the "Anonymous" user, I get all plans with "http://localhost:8085/bamboo520/rest/api/latest/plan" and I can also access "Reports" via the UI when NOT LOGGED IN. 

When I try "http://localhost:8085/bamboo520/rest/api/latest/chart/reports", I get the following:
{code}
<status>
<status-code>401</status-code>
<message>
Client must be authenticated to access this resource.
</message>
</status>
{code}

Every thing is fine if I login or after I try "http://localhost:8085/bamboo520/rest/api/latest/chart/reports/def?os_authType=basic&os_username=admin&os_password=admin" based on the instructions here: [Using the Bamboo REST APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Using+the+Bamboo+REST+APIs]. But I expect the same behavior with these two calls as an anonymous user, especially seeing http://localhost:8085/bamboo520/rest/api/latest/plan used as an example [here|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Using+the+Bamboo+REST+APIs].

If I navigate to Bamboo Admin - > Global Permissions and remove the "Access" permission for the anonymous user, both "http://localhost:8085/bamboo520/rest/api/latest/plan" and "http://localhost:8085/bamboo520/rest/api/latest/chart/reports/" give me a 401 Access Denied error. 

If there are no specific reasons behind this permission settings, please make the calls return the same result to avoid confusion.

fields.description:
The new feature to enable [XSRF protection|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+XSRF+protection] introduced in Bamboo 5.3, causes a crash if the tomcat proxy config are wrongly configured. 
*Steps to reproduced*
# Configure Bamboo to use mod_proxy as detailed here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Apache+HTTP+server
# my current settings is like this:
{code}
ProxyRequests Off
ProxyPreserveHost On

<Proxy *>
    Order deny,allow
    Allow from all
</Proxy>
ProxyPass        /bamboo53 http://localhost:1053/bamboo53 
ProxyPassReverse /bamboo53 http://localhost:1053/bamboo53
<Location /bamboo53>
    Order allow,deny
    Allow from all
</Location>
{code}
# The tomcat connector for Bamboo has proxy related parameters:
{code}
scheme="http"
proxyName="sultan-PC" 
proxyPort="80"	
{code}			 
# Set the base_url of Bamboo as appropriately using the proxy url. In my case	: http://sultan-pc/bamboo53/  
# Try editing the security settings page in Bamboo or even try changing the base URL and you will hit in to the errors below:
{noformat}
2013-12-23 22:35:36,365 INFO [http-bio-1053-exec-4] [AccessLogFilter] bamboo GET http://sultan-PC/bamboo53/rest/menu/latest/appswitcher?_=1387809336291 246387kb
2013-12-23 22:35:39,562 INFO [http-bio-1053-exec-7] [AccessLogFilter] bamboo POST http://sultan-PC/bamboo53/admin/configureSecurity.action 245406kb
2013-12-23 22:35:39,564 WARN [http-bio-1053-exec-7] [BambooXsrfTokenInterceptor] XSRF token validation failed in session:CB91741D0541AB8DEFACB782990944F5 due to XSRF_FAILURE_BAD_REFERRER
2013-12-23 22:35:39,564 ERROR [http-bio-1053-exec-7] [ExceptionMappingInterceptor] XSRF Token Validation failed (XSRF_FAILURE_BAD_REFERRER).
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: XSRF Token Validation failed (XSRF_FAILURE_BAD_REFERRER).
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooXsrfTokenInterceptor.doIntercept(BambooXsrfTokenInterceptor.java:64)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.AbstractBambooInterceptor.intercept(AbstractBambooInterceptor.java:34)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at com.atlassian.xwork.interceptors.AroundInterceptor.intercept(AroundInterceptor.java:25)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at org.apache.struts2.interceptor.FileUploadInterceptor.intercept(FileUploadInterceptor.java:252)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.ModelDrivenInterceptor.intercept(ModelDrivenInterceptor.java:100)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.ChainingInterceptor.intercept(ChainingInterceptor.java:145)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.PrepareInterceptor.doIntercept(PrepareInterceptor.java:171)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.MethodFilterInterceptor.intercept(MethodFilterInterceptor.java:98)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.interceptor.I18nInterceptor.intercept(I18nInterceptor.java:161)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork2.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:246)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.GlobalAdminInterceptor.doIntercept(GlobalAdminInterceptor.java:22)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.AbstractBambooInterceptor.intercept(AbstractBambooInterceptor.java:34)
{noformat}

 What is happening in the above example is that because the proxyName is specified as "sultan-PC" the incoming request 'HOST' header value is changed to "sultan-PC" where as the referrer will have a host of "sultan-pc". As the host comparison is case sensitive the 'referer' check fails. I think just to be safe we should perform a case insensitive comparison of the 'referer' and the 'host' headers host.

*Note*
If one does not configure tomcat to have proxy configuration and passes through the HOST header by using the apache httpd 'ProxyPreserveHost' configuration directive then this issue can be avoided. Because ProxyPreserveHost does not cause the scheme or port to be properly set one has to explicitly configure the tomcat connector to include scheme="https" and the proxyPort="443" when using bamboo behind a https proxy. In such a setup we also recommend setting secure="true" in the tomcat connector configuration.
fields.summary: Bamboo crashes when XSRF protection is enabled and proxy is wrongly configured

fields.description:
h3. Summary
# Missing JIRA issues linked to build
# Limited commits when creating releases

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create 110 commits with each commit have commit message related to JIRA issue "TST-1" until "TST-110"
# Run the plan for these 110 commits in a single build
# Create new release for this build

h3. Expected Results
# JIRA issue "TST-1" until "TST-110" listed in the Build's Issue tab
# When creating new release, it will show 110 commits and 110 JIRA issues compared to the previous release in the Release details (Information on the right side of the following screen)
!create_release.png|thumbnail!
# After release created, the Release Commit tab showing the number 110

h3. Actual Results
Due to the 100 commits limitation in the build:
# Only JIRA issue "TST-1" until "TST-100" (100 issues) listed in the Build's Issue tab
# Only 100 commits and 100 JIRA issues shown in the Release details
# The number 100 shown in the Release Commit tab

h3. Notes
Even though the number 100 shown in the Release Commit tab, the Commit tab still have a message "Showing 100 of 110 code changes"
fields.summary: 100 build commits limitation cause missing JIRA issues linked to build and limited commits shown when creating release

fields.description:
Hi Team

I would like to request an improvement for Bamboo.

We faced the situation that it was necessary to restart Bamboo and leave it in paused mode as the Build servers were off during the Maintenance period.

I would like to request the Bamboo configuration option which can be set  for example from $BAMBOO_HOME/bamboo.properties and will automatically start Banboo in Paused mode.

Please see the [BSP-12222|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-12222] for more details.

Regards,
Areg
fields.summary: Please add the configuration option in Bamboo to allow start in Paused mode

fields.description:
Hi,

Artifacts folders should be cleaned before new build. I don't want deleted files to slip out in production.

We have a build setup where we build the binaries only once (commit stage) and subsequent stages use the same binaries.

To run a script-task as a final task to perform the clean is not a solution for me.
fields.summary: Clean artifact destination folder before new build

fields.description:
We have numerous build projects that are based on git repositories with submodules.  Bamboo correctly picks up and initializes these submodules correctly; however, it does not show commit information or related Jira issues for the submodules.

This reduces the value of Bamboo + Jira integration for our product development team as each build / version in Bamboo only reflects a fraction of the actual activity that is rolled up in that build.
fields.summary: Commits / Issues tabs in build & deployment projects should reflect submodule activity

fields.description: Currently the Artifact Downloader task doesn't replace the files that already exist in the current working directory, and a workaround can be to download the artifacts into a sub-directory (by using the "Destination path" field of the Artifact Downloader task). Add a checkbox in the Artifact Downloader task for requiring the replacement of an existing file if a file with the same name already exists.
fields.summary: Add an option to the Artifact Downloader task to overwrite the file if it exists

fields.description:
Using Bamboo via OnDemand, in both firefox and chrome (latest), I am unable to change the order of jobs in a stage by dragging and dropping.

The reticle allows me to drag the bar representing the job, but when I drag the bar to where it ought to be, it will not drop into its new place.  Instead, it snaps back to its old order.
fields.summary: Cannot change order of jobs via drag and drop

fields.description: Since AWS tags are used to simplify the administration of AWS services, could be very interesting if we could "tag" instances that has been started by Elastic Bamboo and modify existing tagging such as the instance name which is supplied on start-up.
fields.summary: Add the ability to assign or modify AWS tags to Elastic Bamboo triggered instance.

fields.description:
It's very strange that there is no ready made hook for integration stash events with bamboo.

It's obvioulsy needed ready made hook which is called by stash when something is changed and process of compilation respective build plans is exectued with no time.
fields.summary: Stash bamboo hook

fields.description: There is currently no stable or predictable order in the way we list build plan labels under plan summary page. Though, the order that builds were run should have the priority, having the option to change the order based on labels (Either alphabetical ordering or keeping the same order in which labels were assigned originally) will improve readability and can be helpful to review the plan history based on the labels assigned to each build.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# install JIRA 6.1.5

{code}

fields.description:
Currently is only possible to override the Default repository of the plan.
But it's needed you can override all repository definitions in a plan branch.

Example, you have repository for your development and setup a plan with automatic branch management for feature branches. now, if you have another repository in that plan for build tools or own scripts and you need an other branch, it's not possible at the moment to override this second repository.
fields.summary: In Plan Branches it should be possible to override all repository definitions

fields.description: It looks like whenever a subprocess executes, all of the output comes in one big burst, and the newlines here are given timestamps of Jan 1, 1970. I suspect because the log lines are treated as one giant line that happens to have a lot of newlines in it, and thus each line has some sort of timestamp, but the intermediate lines that emerge from having newline characters don't, and JS is forgiving like that where values that aren't there are really kind of like 0 are really kind of like 1970.
fields.summary: Some output has a timestamp of epoch

fields.description:
Currently the task allows you to inject a Bamboo variable value for a job. I'd like this to work for other jobs, stages,...

Currently my workaround is..
- The job that gets the value to be injected creates a txt file, then I share this artifact with other jobs.
- The job that is going to use the Bamboo variable declares a dependency with this artifact, and then injects the variable through the task.

I'd like to inject the value in anywhere in the build plan, and then have access to it.
fields.summary: Make inject variable task have build plan scope

fields.description:
Currently in Bamboo, User Repositories are mutually exclusive.

That is, you can't have local users and also be connected to JIRA / Crowd. In order words, as soon as you select *Users and groups from JIRA or Crowd*, local user become inactive.

This becomes problematic if ever there's a problem with JIRA/Crowd, you'll become locked out of bamboo.

JIRA and Confluence both allow local and Crowd users to be active at the same time.
fields.summary: Allow both local and "remote" users

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce:

- Create a deployment project.
- Deploy it.
- Terminate the agent before the deployment is complete.
- The deployment will now be stuck with deploying status and can't be stopped.

h4. Expected behavior:

Deployment process should automatically detect an agent going offline and failing the job.
 
h4. Workaround:

Restart Bamboo to stop the deployment. For Bamboo OnDemand customers please raise a support ticket at support.atlassian.com to request for restart.
fields.summary: Deployment stuck and can not be stopped when the agent is terminated within the deployment process

fields.description: Currently the dashboard shows some columns like the build number. It will be nice to add the revision as well. The revisions are visible only on the build summary page.
fields.summary: Show revisions on dashboard

fields.description:
As a user, I would like for the command tasks to also be able to process shell substitutions (wildcards, variables an so on) and so on. As in certain tasks, using a command task is more appropriate than using Script tasks, for example:

* Command issue automatically creates requirement for job-to-instance matching mechanism.
* Command gives the user the choice not to care about where executable file resides. On different instances (started from different instance images) same executable may reside in different places. With Command the user just needs to set instance image capabilities.

As suggestion is to add a checkbox in the bottom section of Command task option. This checkbox should say *Process shell substitutions (wildcards, variables and so on)* or something similar.
fields.summary: Add the ability for Command tasks to interpret shell commands

fields.description:
When viewing the Test Summary for a particular test, and you want to see the Recent Failures, the list is determined by the filter chosen on the Recent Failures page. This is confusing since the user may have never set the value on that tab, and thus they won't see any Recent Failures and not know how to adjust the filtering.

In the screenshot, I can see 9 failures in the stats, but none in the list.
fields.summary: Test Summary page takes filter into account even though it is invisible

Unless stuff is being published there, probably it shouldn't appear at all there.
fields.summary: remove Artifacts tab from builds that don't publish artifacts

fields.description:
In order to simplify the use of elastic Windows instances with Bamboo OnDemand it would be helpful to allow mounting an _existing_ EBS volume (or snapshot) to Bamboo-managed instances as /dev/sda1 (the root partition) when spinning them up. This makes it easier to update and maintain the core system. Right now, to my understanding, it's only possible to mount existing EBS volumes as secondary hard drive. Therefore the core Windows installation is always reset to the original image and software updates would need to be installed again.

This is especially useful for WIndows (due to it's architecture with having a registry, etc.). Right now I'm applying a workaround of having the instances always running and in case one has to be stopped or gets terminated for whatever reason, restart a new instance, stop it, attach the previous EBS manually, and start the instance up again.
fields.summary: Bamboo OnDemand: Allow mounting existing EBS volume as /dev/sda1

fields.description:
h3. The context
We have a large enterprise installation with hundreds of teams.

It is useful for them to see the activity and details of other teams projects, so we leave the "view" permission active for all authenticated users.

h3. The Problem
But now that we are using Bamboo 5 with Releases may teams are exposing full ear/war and properties files needed for deployments. Anyone who can authenticate to bamboo can also download all applications artifacts, some of which may be sensitive.

h3. The Desire
Another permission level either globally or plan level (or artifact definition level) that would define additional restrictions to view/download artifacts from a build Plan.


This would apply whether viewing the build plan, or trying to push a release from the related deployment project.
fields.summary: Restrict permissions to view artifacts of a build plan

fields.description:
For each assembly to be tested, you have to explicitly name it in the NUnit task configuration or the .nunit file.
We would like to use a wildcard pattern (e.g. *.Test.dll) to select files for unit testing, rather than having to edit our task or .nunit file every time we add tests.

For reference, see the TeamCity implementation here: http://confluence.jetbrains.com/display/TCD8/NUnit
fields.summary: Allow wildcards for files in the NUnit test runner task

fields.description:
When using artifact of the same plan,  the dest folder would not be cleaned first prior to the download of the artifact. Hence there may be old artifact files remain in the dest directory.

For example, in job 1 you compile a project and make all the output as an artifact for the job 2 to use. The job 2 would take the artifact to do something else. In Build #1, job 1 produces A.DLL. Then the source code changed, in Build #2, job 1 produces B.DLL. Then in Build #2, job 2 would try to download B.DLL to a destination folder set in the plan, say workdirectory\dest. dest would contain both A.DLL and B.DLL now. Because this folder is never cleaned. This behavior is wrong.
fields.summary: using artifact dependency,  the dest folder would not be cleaned first prior to the download of the artifact

fields.description:
Every time Bamboo is started and doesn't have EC2 enabled, it generates a harmless system error (see the attached screenshot) and there is this line in the Bamboo logs:
{code}
2013-12-02 23:08:22,933 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [BambooContainer] Starting Bamboo...
2013-12-02 23:08:22,933 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [BambooContainer] Reticulating splines...
2013-12-02 23:08:22,957 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-4] [BambooSmackClient] No IM server specified. Bamboo Smack client not initialised.
2013-12-02 23:08:22,965 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [AgentManagerImpl] Initialising local agents...
2013-12-02 23:08:22,980 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBuildAgent] Ensuring the temp path '/opt/atlassian/bamboo/temp' exists.
2013-12-02 23:08:22,981 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBuildAgent] Build agent 'Default Agent' started. Waiting for builds...
2013-12-02 23:08:22,981 INFO [7-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-19-thread-1] [BuildAgentControllerImpl] Agent 'Default Agent' ready to take build from queue...
2013-12-02 23:08:22,990 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ElasticImageConfigurationManagerImpl] Checking if stock EC2 images need updating...
2013-12-02 23:08:23,008 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ElasticImageConfigurationManagerImpl] No changes for image ami-430a452a
2013-12-02 23:08:23,022 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ElasticImageConfigurationManagerImpl] No changes for image ami-a10b44c8
2013-12-02 23:08:23,053 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ElasticImageConfigurationManagerImpl] No changes for image ami-976edafe
2013-12-02 23:08:23,093 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ElasticImageConfigurationManagerImpl] No changes for image ami-4488f72d
2013-12-02 23:08:23,101 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ElasticImageConfigurationManagerImpl] No changes for image ami-a30b44ca
2013-12-02 23:08:23,139 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultErrorHandler] Recording an error: Expected 0 or 1 default images for US_EAST_1, EBS, x86_64
{code}

From this [comment below|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-14101?focusedCommentId=704877&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-70487] that offers details and a workaround:

h4. Notes

During startup Bamboo checks if the stock Elastic Image Configuration data shipped with Bamboo matches configuration stored in database. When Bamboo will find any stock Elastic Image Configuration with an outdated AMI ID in database it will update AMI ID in all Elastic Image Configurations which are using the same AMI ID as this outdated stock Elastic Image Configuration. 

The following error
bq. Expected 0 or 1 default images for US_EAST_1, EBS, x86_64
is reported by Bamboo when during startup it will detect multiple stock Elastic Image Configurations which:
- are shipped/managed by Bamboo
- share the same region, root device type, architecture and OS name
- might have different AMI ID

This is an unexpected state that might be caused by:
- a bug in earlier versions of Bamboo (upgrade task creating new entry in {{ELASTIC_IMAGE}} table instead of updating existing one
- manual modification of database

It is possible that customer has created their own Elastic Image Configurations using AMI ID from any of those duplicate stock Elastic Image Configurations. Proceeding with the normal update procedure would mean that Bamboo would modify AMI ID in all those Elastic Image Configuration. We decided not to do it to avoid possibility of altering configuration that was deliberately created by our customers.

h4. Workaround

Customers not using EC2:
# Stop Bamboo
# Run the following query {{delete from ELASTIC_IMAGE where SHIPPED_WITH_BAMBOO = true}}
# Restart Bamboo to recreate entries in {{ELASTIC_IMAGE}} table

Customers using EC2:
# Navigate to Administration > Image configurations and rename one of the duplicate configurations to "DELETE_ME"
# Stop Bamboo
# Run the following query {{delete from ELASTIC_IMAGE where NAME = 'DELETE_ME'}}
# Restart Bamboo to update entries in {{ELASTIC_IMAGE}} table
fields.summary: Elastic Bamboo Error : Expected 0 or 1 default images for US_EAST_1, EBS, x86_64

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
 - Set up a build plan that does some work
 - Set up the Bamboo SMTP server to a known-good server that will accept or relay messages
 - Set up the build plan to notify when a comment is added, using a known-good email address that will accept messages.
 - Build the plan
 - Add a comment via the UI
 -- You should get an email notifying you of the comment changes
 - Add a comment via the REST API:
{code:java}
curl -s -H 'Content-Type: application/xml' -X POST --data-ascii "<comment author='admin'><content>Build Revision: 40691</content></comment>" --user admin:admin "http://localhost:8085/bamboo/rest/api/latest/result/PROJ-EM-1/comment?os_authType=basic"
{code}

 -- You will not get an email, but the comment will appear on he Build Summary page
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't send notifications when adding a comment via REST API call to a build result

fields.description:
I would like to receive an email/SMS when a build (particularly a lengthy build) reaches a manual stage. This will allow me to be immediately notified, saving time and some annoyance in having to manually check whether the step is reached, and assist in timely progress when I am away from my system and need to progress a build that has reached that step quickly. 

For example: I am out on site, and I need to get back to base asap and manually deploy a build that is urgent.
fields.summary: Manual stage reached notification
